Covid-19 made my cancer diagnosis even harder

21/11/2021

Being diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma during the Covid pandemic was a lonely experience

Image by Valentina Sivori

By Molli Tyldesley

In September 2020, I was diagnosedÂ with a blood cancer called Hodgkinâ€™s lymphoma â€“ the most common cancer for young adults to get.Â However, my diagnosis is not the reason I am writing this article. Rather, itÂ is about the lengthy process and subsequent loneliness surrounding my experience, which was largely induced byÂ the effects of Covid-19.

From June to September 2020, IÂ underwent numerous tests. So manyÂ in fact, I have now forgotten what theyÂ were. However, what I do remember isÂ my legs shaking from the sheer anxietyÂ and nerves, as I awaited yet another appointment at my local hospital in Manchester. This was ultimately inconclusive, and resulted in more tests whichÂ meant another two to three weeks ofÂ utter dread as I waited for my results.

Waiting for these appointments wasÂ not in the same realm as waiting in A&EÂ with a potentially broken arm. The similarities are there; waiting time, tiredness, boredom, pain, etc, however, theÂ pain felt waiting for a cancer diagnosisÂ is beyond physical and enters into theÂ world of mental. Time was precious,Â and the impact of Covid-19 on theÂ NHS was a huge problem.

From scans to chemotherapy, theÂ worst part of my whole experience withÂ cancer was the limbo I felt between theÂ possibility of a cancer diagnosis, andÂ the reality of it.Â Following a biopsy in early August,Â I was told I had a 90 percent chance ofÂ having blood cancer. In order to get aÂ diagnosis I was given two options: waitÂ until another hospital had a chance toÂ assess my blood, or go under anaesthetic to have a lymph node surgicallyÂ removed as this could potentially speedÂ the process up. I opted for the latter, as IÂ couldnâ€™t wait any longer.Â Yet with surgery, Covid-19 naturally came into play. From waiting for theÂ appointment, having several invasiveÂ Covid-19 tests and isolating before theÂ surgery, the whole process felt unnecessarily difficult and challenging.

AnotherÂ blow came when I was told the worstÂ thing that I could possibly do is catchÂ Covid-19 before any staging or treatment began. This left me trapped in myÂ house and alone in my thoughts for another unknown period of time.

However, it wasnâ€™t all doom andÂ gloom. After the confirmation of my diagnosis, I was sent to The Christie Hospital in Manchester. A place renownedÂ for its impeccable care and treatment,Â I knew I was in safe hands as soon as IÂ had my first meeting with my specialist doctors. The delay to treatment dueÂ to the Covid-19 lag time was never inÂ the picture, and waiting for scans wasÂ only as tiresome and scary as it wouldÂ have been pre-Covid-19. Yet, this didÂ not mean Covid-19 didnâ€™t exist withinÂ the walls of the Christie; single file, faceÂ masks and social distancing prevailed.

"It is foreign enough to try and navigate a cancer diagnosis at 20 years oldÂ without having to try and understand aÂ pandemic at the same time."

Although Covid-19 is statisticallyÂ less dangerous for young adults, this isÂ not the case for cancer patients needingÂ chemotherapy, as the treatment wipesÂ out your immune system. I had to reinforce this to family and friends, emphasising the severity of the situationÂ if I was to become ill, which becameÂ another additional stress.Â Catching Covid-19 would alsoÂ mean I would be unable to receive treatment at my allocated time, therefore delaying the potential end date. My family and I had to deal with an incredibleÂ amount of anxiety, with the hospitalÂ staff having to learn numerous detailsÂ about my parents and those close toÂ me as I became â€œclinically extremelyÂ vulnerableâ€, and the consequences ofÂ a Covid-19 contact became incrediblyÂ severe.

This meant I was in full isolationÂ from the moment of my diagnosis inÂ September, until I was vaccinated inÂ January; I couldnâ€™t leave my house to goÂ to the local shop to get a drink, for fear IÂ could potentially get Covid-19.Â The scariest part of my treatmentÂ though, was the prospect of facing itÂ alone without the support of my family and friends. Cancer is not something you want to tackle on your ownÂ â€“ nevermind at 20 years old. I still donâ€™tÂ know how to do my own bills, let aloneÂ receive life changing information, or goÂ into a room and have painful chemotherapy. Yet this was the status quo.

The impact of this was not feltÂ solely by me, but rather potentiallyÂ every other young adult facing cancer.Â So much so, Teenage Cancer TrustÂ and CLIC Sergeant began a campaignÂ named â€˜Hand2holdâ€™ which called for aÂ commitment from the Government toÂ allow â€“ where possible â€“ young adultsÂ to be accompanied during key moments in cancer diagnosis and treatment. This was an essential move andÂ one that highlights the impact of Covid-19 on cancer diagnosis and treatment, especially for young adults.Â If I could have had my sister or myÂ friends with me during my treatment,Â taking my mind off it and making meÂ laugh, who knows how much better IÂ would have felt about my diagnosis. Additionally, I would have loved to haveÂ my parents present with me when I gotÂ the good news about being cured soÂ early on! To share those moments, andÂ have a hand to hold may have changedÂ my whole experience and mental wellbeing.

Here, I want to make a note thatÂ should underpin this whole article andÂ is important to mention. This is not toÂ say the staff that I came into contactÂ with and those who were working behind the scene were at fault.Â Every single person I met along theÂ way worked tirelessly to help me andÂ others so we didnâ€™t feel alone, so weÂ were not scared and we felt as normalÂ as possible. I was cared for every stepÂ of the way and I will always be gratefulÂ for every person who worked under theÂ pressures of Covid-19 in hospitals toÂ provide the best care possible.Â It is foreign enough to try and navigate a cancer diagnosis at 20 years oldÂ without having to try and understand aÂ pandemic at the same time.
